comment_text.mn68:1.2: The Buddha is recorded as visiting this grove in two other discourses, which share a common narrative; both deal with the growth of spiritual qualities (AN 10.67, AN 10.68).
comment_text.mn68:2.1: This makes it sound like they had gone forth recently, which would date this discourse to the early years of the dispensation.
comment_text.mn68:2.2: Pali editions vary a little in the exact monks mentioned.
comment_text.mn68:4.2: Reading te va as in PTS. Here the Buddha switches from addressing the monks as a whole to addressing just Anuruddha and his friends.
comment_text.mn68:5.4: Also at SN 22.80:6.4 and Iti 91:2.4. The terms here follow the same sequence as in the Vinaya account of ordination. Generally, ordination should not be given in such cases, but if it is given, those performing it incur an offense of wrong-doing. | Soldiers joined the Sangha to escape military service, so the Buddha said one should not ordain those in service to a king (Kd 1:40.1.1). | Several rules regarding ordination of criminals were passed, the thrust of which is that wanted outlaws should not be ordained (Kd 1:41.1.1). | Another man ordained to escape debt (Kd 1:46.1.1). | “In fear” (bhayaṭṭa) is the only item that does not straightforwardly correspond to the Vinaya sequence, where instead the ordination of slaves appears at this point (Kd 1:47.1.1). But a connection is suggested by the verses of the water-carrier Puṇṇikā, who speaks of living “in fear” of her masters’ abuse and beatings. | Seventeen boys ordained as novices to get a nice livelihood (Kd 1:49.1.1).
comment_text.mn68:6.2: This is the first absorption, lacking which the mind is full of hindrances. It appears that here the Buddha is explaining the benefits of absorption to Anuruddha, making this the first of several suttas concerned with Anuruddha’s meditative progress (MN 128, AN 3.130 , MN 31).
comment_text.mn68:7.3: Of the seven methods given at MN 2:4.1, this omits “seeing”, “restraint”, and “developing”. The Buddha is asking whether his use of the four remaining methods gives the impression he is secretly acting from defilements. It seems to me that this question is speaking to a common tendency among young, idealistic practitioners to expect the teacher to completely transcend worldly activities. But then they see the teacher eating food (like someone desiring taste) or avoiding dangerous situations (like someone worried about their body). When they do such things, it comes from a place of attachment, so it is only natural to wonder if the same applies to the teacher as well. Someone who has experienced, at minimum, the first absorption has known what it is like for the mind to be temporarily free of such attachments, hence would not have such thoughts.
comment_text.mn68:8.3: At SN 44.9 the six ascetic teachers are each said to do this, and the Buddha does it at DN 16:2.5.1 = DN 18:1.4. | This can be seen as a preemptive teaching to Anuruddha, who was to master the clairvoyance that makes such insights possible. The Buddha wants him to know that such abilities should only be used for pure reasons.

root_text.mn68:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā kulaputtā bhagavantaṁ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā honti—

root_text.mn68:3.1: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
root_text.mn68:3.2: Atha kho bhagavā te kulaputte ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.mn68:3.3: “ye te, bhikkhave, kulaputtā mamaṁ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, kacci te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū abhiratā brahmacariye”ti?
root_text.mn68:3.4: Evaṁ vutte, te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.mn68:3.5: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā te kulaputte ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.mn68:3.6: “ye te, bhikkhave, kulaputtā mamaṁ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, kacci te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū abhiratā brahmacariye”ti?
root_text.mn68:3.7: Dutiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.mn68:3.8: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā te kulaputte ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:

root_text.mn68:3.10: Tatiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.mn68:4.3: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn68:5.2: Etaṁ kho, anuruddhā, tumhākaṁ patirūpaṁ kulaputtānaṁ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitānaṁ yaṁ tumhe abhirameyyātha brahmacariye.
root_text.mn68:5.3: Yena tumhe, anuruddhā, bhadrena yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā susukāḷakesā kāme paribhuñjeyyātha tena tumhe, anuruddhā, bhadrenapi yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā susukāḷakesā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā.
root_text.mn68:5.4: Te ca kho pana tumhe, anuruddhā, neva rājābhinītā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, na corābhinītā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, na iṇaṭṭā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, na bhayaṭṭā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, nājīvikāpakatā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā.
root_text.mn68:5.5: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
root_text.mn68:5.6: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti—
root_text.mn68:5.7: nanu tumhe, anuruddhā, evaṁ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā”ti?
root_text.mn68:6.1: “Evaṁ pabbajitena ca pana, anuruddhā, kulaputtena kimassa karaṇīyaṁ?

root_text.mn68:8.2: kaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno tathāgato sāvake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti:
root_text.mn68:8.4: “Bhagavaṁmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṁnettikā bhagavaṁpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṁyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
root_text.mn68:9.1: “Na kho, anuruddhā, tathāgato janakuhanatthaṁ na janalapanatthaṁ na lābhasakkārasilokānisaṁsatthaṁ na ‘iti maṁ jano jānātū’ti sāvake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti:
root_text.mn68:9.3: Santi ca kho, anuruddhā, kulaputtā saddhā uḷāravedā uḷārapāmojjā.
root_text.mn68:9.4: Te taṁ sutvā tadatthāya cittaṁ upasaṁharanti.
root_text.mn68:9.5: Tesaṁ taṁ, anuruddhā, hoti dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn68:10.5: So kho panassa āyasmā sāmaṁ diṭṭho vā hoti anussavassuto vā:
root_text.mn68:10.6: ‘evaṁsīlo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṁdhammo so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṁpañño so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṁvihārī so āyasmā ahosi itipi, evaṁvimutto so āyasmā ahosi itipī’ti.
root_text.mn68:10.7: So tassa saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussaranto tadatthāya cittaṁ upasaṁharati.
root_text.mn68:10.8: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, bhikkhuno phāsuvihāro hoti.

root_text.mn68:23.5: Sā kho panassā bhaginī sāmaṁ diṭṭhā vā hoti anussavassutā vā:
root_text.mn68:23.6: ‘evaṁsīlā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṁdhammā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṁpaññā sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṁvihārinī sā bhaginī ahosi itipi, evaṁvimuttā sā bhaginī ahosi itipī’ti.
root_text.mn68:23.7: Sā tassā saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarantī tadatthāya cittaṁ upasaṁharati.
root_text.mn68:23.8: Evampi kho, anuruddhā, upāsikāya phāsuvihāro hoti.
root_text.mn68:24.1: Iti kho, anuruddhā, tathāgato na janakuhanatthaṁ na janalapanatthaṁ na lābhasakkārasilokānisaṁsatthaṁ na ‘iti maṁ jano jānātū’ti sāvake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti:
root_text.mn68:24.3: Santi ca kho, anuruddhā, kulaputtā saddhā uḷāravedā uḷārapāmojjā.
root_text.mn68:24.4: Te taṁ sutvā tadatthāya cittaṁ upasaṁharanti.
root_text.mn68:24.5: Tesaṁ taṁ, anuruddhā, hoti dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.mn68:24.7: Attamano āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn68:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans near Naḷakapāna in the grove of flame-of-the-forest trees.
translation_text.mn68:2.1: Now at that time several very well-known gentlemen had gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha’s name—
translation_text.mn68:2.2: The venerables Anuruddha, Bhaddiya, Kimbila, Bhagu, Koṇḍañña, Revata, Ānanda, and other very well-known gentlemen.
translation_text.mn68:3.1: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting in the open, surrounded by the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn68:3.2: Then the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about those gentlemen:
translation_text.mn68:3.3: “Mendicants, those gentlemen who have gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness in my name—I trust they’re satisfied with the spiritual life?”
translation_text.mn68:3.4: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.
translation_text.mn68:3.5: For a second and a third time the Buddha asked the same question.
translation_text.mn68:3.10: For a third time, the mendicants kept silent.
translation_text.mn68:4.1: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn68:4.2: “Why don’t I question just those gentlemen?”
translation_text.mn68:4.3: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Anuruddha,
translation_text.mn68:4.4: “Anuruddha and friends, I hope you’re satisfied with the spiritual life?”
translation_text.mn68:4.5: “Indeed, sir, we are satisfied with the spiritual life.”
translation_text.mn68:5.2: It’s appropriate for gentlemen like yourselves, who have gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, to be satisfied with the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn68:5.3: Since you’re blessed with youth, in the prime of life, with pristine black hair, you could have enjoyed sensual pleasures; yet you have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn68:5.4: But you didn’t go forth to escape a summons by a king or a summons for a bandit, or because you were in debt or in fear, or in order to make a living.
translation_text.mn68:5.5: Rather, didn’t you go forth thinking: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn68:5.6: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering’?”
translation_text.mn68:6.1: “But, Anuruddha and friends, when a gentleman has gone forth like this, what should he do?
translation_text.mn68:6.2: Take someone who doesn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that. Their mind is still occupied by desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, doubt, discontent, and sloth.
translation_text.mn68:6.3: That’s someone who doesn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that.
translation_text.mn68:6.4: Take someone who does achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that. Their mind is not occupied by desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, doubt, discontent, and sloth.
translation_text.mn68:6.5: That’s someone who does achieve the rapture and bliss that are secluded from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that.
translation_text.mn68:7.1: Is this what you think of me?
translation_text.mn68:7.2: ‘The Realized One has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn68:7.3: That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and dispels some things.’”
translation_text.mn68:7.4: “No sir, we don’t think of you that way.
translation_text.mn68:7.7: We think of you this way:
translation_text.mn68:7.8: ‘The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn68:7.9: That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and dispels some things.’”
translation_text.mn68:7.11: The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn68:7.12: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,
translation_text.mn68:7.13: in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn68:7.14: That’s why, after appraisal, he uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and dispels some things.
translation_text.mn68:8.1: What do you think, Anuruddha and friends?
translation_text.mn68:8.2: What advantage does the Realized One see in declaring the rebirth of his disciples who have passed away:
translation_text.mn68:8.3: ‘This one is reborn here, while that one is reborn there’?”
translation_text.mn68:8.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn68:9.1: “The Realized One does not declare such things for the sake of fawning or flattering people, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’
translation_text.mn68:9.3: Rather, there are gentlemen of faith who are full of sublime joy and gladness.
translation_text.mn68:9.4: When they hear that, they apply their minds to that end.
translation_text.mn68:9.5: That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn68:10.1: Take a monk who hears this:
translation_text.mn68:10.2: ‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.
translation_text.mn68:10.5: And he’s either seen for himself, or heard from someone else, that that venerable
translation_text.mn68:10.6: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.
translation_text.mn68:10.7: Recollecting that monk’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, he applies his mind to that end.
translation_text.mn68:10.8: That’s how a monk lives at ease.
translation_text.mn68:11.1: Take a monk who hears this:
translation_text.mn68:11.2: ‘The monk named so-and-so has passed away.
translation_text.mn68:11.4: with the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.’
translation_text.mn68:11.5: And he’s either seen for himself, or heard from someone else, that that venerable
translation_text.mn68:11.6: had such ethics, such qualities, such wisdom, such meditation, or such freedom.
translation_text.mn68:11.7: Recollecting that monk’s faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom, he applies his mind to that end.

translation_text.mn68:24.1: So it’s not for the sake of fawning or flattering people, nor for the benefit of possessions, honor, or popularity, nor thinking, ‘So let people know about me!’ that the Realized One declares the rebirth of his disciples who have passed away:
translation_text.mn68:24.2: ‘This one is reborn here, while that one is reborn there.’
translation_text.mn68:24.3: Rather, there are gentlemen of faith who are full of joy and gladness.
translation_text.mn68:24.4: When they hear that, they apply their minds to that end.
translation_text.mn68:24.5: That is for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.mn68:24.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn68:24.7: Satisfied, Venerable Anuruddha approved what the Buddha said.
